title: 114_hr1300
content: The Act titled "First Responder Anthrax Preparedness Act" establishes a pre-event anthrax vaccination program for emergency response providers under the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The Act establishes a program to provide anthrax vaccines to emergency response providers at high risk of exposure, nearing expiration, with logistical support, disclosures on benefits and risks, and outreach for education. The Act establishes a program to provide anthrax vaccines to emergency response providers at high risk of exposure, with logistical support, risk assessments, intelligence sharing, and tailored analytical support for anthrax threats. The Act establishes a program to provide anthrax vaccines to emergency response providers at high risk of exposure, with logistical support, risk assessments, intelligence sharing, and tailored analytical support for anthrax threats. 1(b) of such Act is amended by inserting at the end of the items relating to title V the following new item: The Act establishes a pilot program to provide anthrax vaccines to emergency response providers for 24 months, with preliminary requirements to be met before implementation. The pilot program for anthrax vaccines includes establishing a communication platform, education and training modules, conducting economic analysis, and creating a logistical platform for vaccine requests. The Secretary of Homeland Security will select emergency response providers from at least two states for participation. Providers will receive disclosures and educational materials. The Secretary of Homeland Security will submit annual reports on the progress and results of the pilot program for anthrax vaccines, including the percentage of eligible emergency response providers volunteering, and the vaccination rates among participants. The Secretary of Homeland Security will implement a pilot program for emergency response providers to receive necessary vaccinations within one year of the Act's enactment. The program aims to improve participation rates and provide vaccines under the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The House of Representatives passed the bill on July 29, 2015. Karen L. Haas attested to it as the Clerk.
